Then again I use my local language when speaking with my family members but still friends who had no clue of my language still responded in English? So the same question, how this synchronicity got manifested if the friend who I had the synchronicity with had no clue of my local language? Therefore by c
onsidering all, my mind directly affecting the minds of my friends consciously or unconsciously, minds of people who worked for these companies directly or their minds directly affecting my mind consciously or unconsciously is another controversial proposition. It's apparent that our minds are being affected, there's no controversy on that, however, when we finding the cause behind it, the only logical conclusion that we can hold onto is that it's due to an external process that we haven't identified yet. This external process clearly shows intelligence. Clearly, it has access to our thoughts, it's interacting with our brains and influencing our minds, our decisions. It also shows that it could intelligently manipulate our perceptions, which means, it should understand human perceptions well. What can I say about this external process? 1). It acted on its own. each me. 2). The phenomena clearly showed decision-making capabilities. 3). It must be able to create these synchronicities with anyone on Earth in complicated ways. 4). I continued my research and I clearly observed that there were times that this intelligence acted instantly. For example when I do my research and whenever I got insightful thoughts, I got sudden calls from my friends/family members, etc.., I got emails, messages from applications such as WhatsApp, Viber, etc.. just to disrupt my thinking and also instantaneous disruption to power continued regardless of where I stayed. ighly abnormal synchronicities, the theme of these synchronicities has once again changed. By considering all, can we say that a natural cause behind my experiences? I don't find convincing evidence to hold onto such a view. The phenomena showed to many synchronicities, just like it had its own mind and showed me decision-making capabilities again and again. Thereafter, I still continued my research to understand this phenomena, whenever I managed to have insightful thoughts, there were so many occasions that I got sudden calls from friends, family members and even from unknown people, I instantly got emails, I still faced disruption to my Internet and power regardless of my location. And then I started sneezing whenever I had an insightful thought at that very moment. Therefore, today by considering all, I had to conclude that an unidentified mind-boggling technology is behind this. Let me mention this strange experience also separately: A few months after I facing strange synchronicities for the first time, 
one day I literally got floated above my bed at least an inch. One could find this hard to believe but I was awake when this was happening. This happened less than 15 minutes after I go to bed, around 2.30, 3 in the morning. My bed had a plastic covering so it produces this sound when pressure is applied and releases. I was sleeping sideways and suddenly my body started floating. I instantly listened to the sound coming from the mattress whilst watching this just to confirm that this is really happening and now I'm giving close attention to my entire body, I feel less and less pressure coming from the side of the body that touches the mattress, and now I clearly know that certain parts of my body are not touching the mattress at all. I floated at least an inch from the bed stayed there for a few seconds. The total vertical movement must have been more than an inch. I got afraid to move my body and I'm still observing this strange phenomenon but then gradually my body again lowered back to the bed. Again I can 
now hear the sound of the mattress since my body again started pressing the mattress and I can feel the pressure as my body gradually falling down to the same sleeping position. Even after I go back to the bed, I kept on thinking for a couple of seconds further without moving my body to make sure that this is over. Thereafter, that night I kept on thinking what on Earth happened to me, what could be the reason behind this but I did not find an explanation. When I was carrying out my research, I found another individual who has been having similar experiences. He has been having this experience for over 4 years and once he has been treated for schizophrenia too. He believed that there's a gang who is stalking him. No matter which city he travels he observed these stalkers were there. ught that's how these stalkers know him. Based on my experience, I knew that this cannot be true, therefore, I had so many calls with him and explained to him how to look at the phenomena. Although at that time, I told him that the NSA has the technology, today I know that this is not true either. He no longer believes that the stalkers are there in any of the cities, neither he believes that these people have hacked his house. He understood the existence of phenomena but then again he understood that the other beliefs he had are not actually true. He also started having a normal life. Therefore, not only that I managed to come out of it, I managed to change the belief of anot
her person, a person who has been treated for schizophrenia. What is the implication of this? It's obvious that the observations and the conclusions made by the medical community are also false. What could be the case if I had consulted psychiatric services? What can you do if you ever had to conclude that you get messages from TV or Radio? Or if you happened to conclude that people who are living in your city know you? Or people around the world know you? Famous people know you? Generally, you will have these erroneous conclusions by observing these synchronicities for a long time only. This will not happen overnight. This experience will be so real to you because of the way these synchronicities are manifesting, therefore, you will not listen to others even if they claim that it's not true or if someone claims that it's a mental illness. This is not a mental illness as the medical community thinks. You will also find it hard to explain your experience to another person. Try to logically analyze the experien
ce when you are observing these synchronicities on a daily basis and find out logical reasons to understand that these are synchronicities or meaningful events only this is why you would see controversies for your belief. (This study has been carried out at the Department of Psychology, Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU)) ""Behavioural Experiment: Setting up a confrontation Next, the therapist approached _NAME_ belief that a particular policeman led the persecution of him. This policeman had worked in the drug squad. _NAME_ believed that because he had sold drugs this policeman hunted him. _NAME_ delusion was based on an actual person, so the policeman (now living in another city) was contacted to see if he would meet with _NAME_. The therapist explained the background for this rather peculiar request to the policeman, and he agreed to meet them to answer specific questions _NAME_ had prepared for him. The meeting was set up as a behavioral experiment, and _NAME_ was given t
wo tasks: To prepare concrete questions for the meeting, and to hypothesize how the policeman would look, behave, speak and answer his questions. The questions and hypotheses with the expected outcome were formulated as a questionnaire prior to the meeting. A tape recorder 17 was used during the meeting to ensure accuracy in later discussions between the therapist and _NAME_. As anticipated from the therapist's phone call with the police officer, the officer proved to be competent and understanding and had no problems handling _NAME_ questions and accusations. The meeting resulted in _NAME_ becoming more certain that this policeman could not be a part of the plot against him"" https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/_PHONE_NO_.pdf Since I understood that my brain areas related to thought perception and other areas are being affected and since I understood that synchronicities are the reason behind above delusions, I doubted about voices too. 175920683,"Some things I do to calm down are: Put an ice pack on the back of your head. This will cool down your brain and reduce activity in your limbic system, where emotions happen. Do a task with simple, clear steps. I like baking. I follow the recipe, and it’s easy enough that I don’t get frustrated, but it requires enough concentration that I don’t have room to think about other things. Cleaning also helps. Engage your five senses. This will remind you what is real and what isn’t. Listen to soothing music. Smell something pleasant, like an essential oil. Suck on a hard candy. Look at pictures of things you enjoy. Feel something with an interesting texture, like a piece of Velcro or a stress ball. Try to levitate something with your mind. You obviously won’t succeed, but it gets you to focus all of your attention on a single point outside your body, instead of on your thoughts. I like to use this on airplanes or in public places, because it doesn’t require you to move at all. It looks like yo
u’re just daydreaming to observers. Listen to a guided meditation recording Student Wellness Center – 11 Jun 18 Guided Audio Recordings"

175920703,"Thank you so much Rakkma! This is really helpful When I did finally go to the doctors they gave me Xanax and ssris. I took the Xanax as soon as I left the chemist and they calmed me down instantly, they were really amazing! The problem was was that they are addictive and I hadn't got many so I had to ration them and take half only when I was on the verge of a panic attack, which meant I was still feeling crippling anxiety. The SSRIs I was very afraid of. I read lots of bad reports online and the main reason I didn't end up taking them was because I was terrified they would give me depression or numb my emotions. I know that they work well for lots of people and that's amazing if they do! But I have anxiety about taking them and I feel my brain already has negative outlook from reading bad things online, which I probably shouldn't do. I went to the doctors and told her that I didn't want to take the SSRIs just yet and I wanted more Xanax and she prescribed me Beta Blockers instead. They slow my hear
t rate down and have a very similar effect to the benzodiazapines. The great thing about BBs are that they are not addictive so I could take them every day if I wanted. The doctor recommended that I took them every day for a month but I decided to use them the same as the Xanax and just take them when I feel panic attacks coming. This means I'm not becoming reliant on medication. Mindfulness meditation has been an absolute saviour! I did it 3 times a day sometimes it has completely changed the way I think! I have tried so many methods from life coach videos, _NAME_ talks, podcasts, apps, documentaries and one thing that I find really helpful is finding out other people's stories and how the deal with their struggles. So thanks again for your amazing help! I completely agree with what you say about not worrying when it will happen or if it will go away. As soon as I accepted anxiety as a normal things that happens to many many people I didn't feel so afraid anymore. When I can feel it now I kind of just think 
'do your worst' and I don't feel so bad. It's still scary and I know it will always reoccur and just happy I know that it will pass! I also started to realise that there was no factual evidence that I was going crazy, and this had all been my anxiety. Once I realised this, I started to relax more. I'm far from being fixed but I'm getting there Like you say I will never be rid of it but as each day passes I'm slowly becoming my old self again and its unrecognisable to those around me! I have just started CBT I actually have my second session tomorrow"

175920730,"Also weight loss tips from a science major who has taken many courses that taught about weight loss, nutrition, etc. The best way to lose weight and KEEP IT OFF -do not try to lose weight rapidly, aim for 1 lb a week, slow weight loss is more likely to stay off, this is because it gives your body time to adjust to a new metabolism and weight, if you lose weight too rapidly your body thinks you are starving and food is scare in the environment, this switches it into survival mode where it wants to store fat and the second you eat bad again or stop restricting calories you will gain all the weight back, also it is just not healthy to lose tons of weight rapidly and be in starvation mode there are many cons to health -exercise AND change your diet: as I posted recently, if you just change your diet you are emptying out fat cells but not getting rid of them, thus if you eat bad again or too much they will fill up again and you will gain weight back quickly, if you exercise and can change these fat cell
s to muscle they will be gone and your metabolism speeds up making it easier to lose weight and keep it off! -Weigh yourself every day to keep yourself accountable, the best time to weigh yourself is right after you wake up before you eat anything as you will not have any water weight or food weight on you, you can have as much as a 2 lb difference between your morning and evening weights!! And never weigh yourself while wet that can add on a ton of weight and give you an inaccurate reading, even if you’re just kind of damp."

175920742,"Coronavirus: history, definition and etymology The word was introduced by a group of virologists as a short article “Coronaviruses” in the “News and Views” section of Nature (vol. 220, no. 5168, November 16, 1968, p. 650): “…avian infectious bronchitis virus has a characteristic electron microscopic appearance resembling, but distinct from, that of myxoviruses. Particles are more or less rounded in profile…there is also a characteristic ‘fringe’ of projections 200 ? long, which are rounded or petal shaped, rather than sharp or pointed, as in the myxoviruses. This appearance, recalling the solar corona, is shared by mouse hepatitis virus….In the opinion of the eight virologists these viruses are members of a previously unrecognized group which they suggest should be called the coronaviruses, to recall the characteristic appearance by which these viruses are identified in the electron microscope.” any of a family ( Coronaviridae ) of single-stranded RNA viruses that have a lipid 
envelope studded with club-shaped projections, infect birds and many mammals including humans, and include the causative agents of [MERS] and [SARS]. =Merriam-_NAME_ Coronaviruses (CoV) are a large family of viruses that cause illness ranging from the common cold to more severe diseases such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS-CoV) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS-CoV). Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) is a new strain that was discovered in 2019 and has not been previously identified in humans. Coronaviruses are zoonotic, meaning they are transmitted between animals and people. Detailed investigations found that SARS-CoV was transmitted from civet cats to humans and MERS-CoV from dromedary camels to humans. Several known coronaviruses are circulating in animals that have not yet infected humans. =World Health Organisation"

175920785,"In the context of mental illness, seeking attention is a very good thing. We can’t deal with everything ourselves. We need support from outside sources. That’s the nature of being sick. Therapy, CMHT calls, pdoc visits, these are all types of attention, but they’re also the necessary treatment for our illness. Even outside the context of mental illness, all humans need attention. We are social creatures, and pretending to be overly self-sufficient really harms the human brain. Human interaction is a human need, right up there with food, water, and shelter. Knowing when to ask for help and then accepting the help offered is a sign of strength. You’re stronger when you rely on your social supports. You’ve been trying to give up drinking, and that’s not something most people manage without a strong social safety net. I personally love when people ask for help or attention, because they are relying on useful coping methods to get them through hard times, rather than self-destructing."

175920820,"I had to move in with my dad when I was 29. I had no job and just a little extra money. I had nothing to do all day while he was at work and I was in the middle of a nasty relapse and I was heavy into smoking crack. I slept in a back bedroom on an old mattress on the floor and 4/5 of the floor was used as a storage space for old furniture and boxes of junk. I was not happy to say the least and I called the police a couple times to take me to the psyche ward during that time. In the psyche ward they strapped me face down to a table with leather straps and some other poor guy was strapped down on a table next to me. Oh hell, those were bad times, just horrible times. But I discovered a day program at the county hospital and joined it. We played board games or Charades, or played volleyball out back and went for walks and had therapy groups. It was very informal. But a couple times after day treatment I walked next door to the psyche ward and checked myself in. Did I mention those were horrible times? 
One day my dad said to me, ""Why don’t you get a job? So I went out and found a job at a warehouse. Stayed about two months then walked out at lunchtime one day and never went back. And I called them up and they fired me as a formality. Anyways, I lived with my dad and did some things in my life that really pissed him off but he stuck with me. Then in rapid succession, I moved out of my dads to a group home, I got clean and sober there, I got a job, I moved into a board & care and enrolled myself in college. I started going to AA, CA and NA meetings until I was walking or taking the bus to 5 or 6 meetings a week. I’ve been working almost steadily ever since. That is how I changed my life. Hell, I didn’t want to be addicted to crack, I didn’t want to sleep on the floor, I didn’t want to be in the psyche ward, I didn’t want to be in that day program, I didn’t want to be broke and unemployed. But I was 29 years old and all of those things. So I changed my life and changed all those things. Now I li
ve in an OK apartment, my job ain’t bad at all, I have a nice 2012 Volkswagen Jetta, I take one online class at a time. I shop, cook and clean for myself. I have a couple grand in the bank and take care of my own finances. Sometimes I’m happy, sometimes I’m not. But just forcing myself to do things that sucked at the time got me this place. My motto is the NIKE shoe motto: “Just Do It”. I still do a lot of things I don’t like doing and I have a few toxic people in my life, but all in all, my life ain’t that bad all the time. Change ain’t easy most of the time, it can be very uncomfortable and difficult but I’m glad I went down the path I did when I was younger. The _NAME_ Band has that famous song “Jet Airliner” A line goes, “You got to go through hell before you get to heaven.” That couldn’t be truer. Nothing good comes easy. But I showed how I was down like a 100% of us are at many points in our lives, living with my dad with zero going for me except that I took some risks. And i
t payed off. I hope someone gets something from this."

175920829,"The orthodox view is that what you eat doesn’t affect the body’s pH balance since it is so tightly regulated, but they act as if you could eat any amount of acidic foods without consequence. The key here is the alkaline buffer. Most people are depleted in the minerals that comprise it due to the standard American diet, so their well-being suffers while the body barely maintains the low end of the livable pH range (around 7.35.) The body depletes alkaline calcium from bones to maintain that, too. Osteoporosis, anyone?"

175920835,"Patients with early onset psychosis may benefit from treatment for depression, including with anti-depressants alongside other medication, new research shows. According to scientists at the University of Birmingham’s Institute for Mental Health, depression may be an intrinsic part of early phase psychotic disorders that should be treated together with other more prominent symptoms to improve patient outcomes. https://www.birmingham.ac.uk/news/latest/2020/08/targeted-treatment-for-depression-could-benefit-patients-with-psychosis.aspx"

175920863,"I was told by my first pdoc that every time you quit your meds and then start taking them again they can lose effectiveness. Going on and off your meds too many times and they may stop working altogether, then you will have no relief from your suffering. If you are fine without meds then you’re lucky and that is a different story. However, if you are doing well with meds, and the side effects are minimal or tolerable I would recommend you stay on them"

In most cases, the clots are small and are not deadly, but they can damage the lung."" Maybe you have a small blood clot in your lung.. possibly from smoking.. ness of breath include asthma, bronchitis, pneumonia, pneumothorax, anemia, lung cancer, inhalation injury, pulmonary embolism, anxiety, COPD, high altitude with lower oxygen levels, congestive heart failure, arrhythmia, allergic reaction, anaphylaxis, subglottic stenosis, interstitial lung disease, ... etc... 174333489,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov The effects of age and sex on cognitive impairment in schizophrenia: Findings from the Consortium on the Genetics of Schizophrenia (COGS) study. _NAME_, _PERSON_ Green, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, LC _PERSON_, _PERSON_ Light, AD _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_ Stone, _PERSON_ Sugar, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_ and _PERSON_, PloS one, 2020 Recently emerging evidence indicates accelerated age-related changes in the structure and function of the brain in schizophrenia, raising a question about its potential consequences on cognitive function. Using a large sample of schizophrenia patients and controls and a battery of tasks across multiple cognitive domains, we examined whether patients show accelerated age-related decline in cognition and whether an age-related effect differ between females and males. We utilized data of 1,415 schizophrenia patients and 1,062 healthy community collected by the second phase of the Consortium 
on the Genetics of Schizophrenia (COGS-2). A battery of cognitive tasks included the Letter-Number Span Task, two forms of the Continuous Performance Test, the California Verbal Learning Test, Second Edition, the Penn Emotion Identification Test and the Penn Facial Memory Test. The effect of age and gender on cognitive performance was examined with a general linear model. We observed age-related changes on most cognitive measures, which was similar between males and females. Compared to controls, patients showed greater deterioration in performance on attention/vigilance and greater slowness of processing social information with increasing age. However, controls showed greater age-related changes in working memory and verbal memory compared to patients. Age-related changes (?2p of 0.001 to .008) were much smaller than between-group differences (?2p of 0.005 to .037). This study found that patients showed continued decline of cognition on some domains but stable impairment or even less decline on other domains 
with increasing age. These findings indicate that age-related changes in cognition in schizophrenia are subtle and not uniform across multiple cognitive domains."

175920970,"That’s unfortunate, I feel fantastic when I take it. As I mentioned earlier it has about a 12 hour half life. That means it take 12 hours for 1/2 of the medication to leave your body. After 24 hours only 1/4 will be left, after 2 days only 1/16 will be left. So it should wear off within a day or two. It takes about 4-5 half lives before most medications lose all therapeutic effect."

( not _PERSON_), lived alone and did not appear to socialize with anyone on a regular basis. _NAME_, the fella across the street, would proactively (value added! ) do heavy work for Mr. _PERSON_., such as uprooting and disposing of a small dead sapling from Mr. _PERSON_.'s front lawn. Daily, without fail, Mr. _PERSON_. went for walks of several miles. In winter, he would shovel snow from his own sidewalk. In summer, he would mow his own lawn. He was solitary and independent. One summer day, the neighbor kid stopped by to say, ""Hi."", and discovered that Mr. _PERSON_. had died quietly, sitting in a folding chair in his driveway reading his mail. Independent to the end. After his death, I spoke with one of the firefighters who showed up for such 'events'. He said Mr. _PERSON_.'s home was, ""spotless"". * * * So, yes, lo
nerism/hermitism can be realistic all the way to the glorious end if you have a handful or even one capable, respectfully helpful, and trustworthy neighbor who 'gets' you and keeps a non-intrusive eye on you, and you are disciplined and take excellent care of your health. Lowering stress is vital. One of the few useful things I learned in college on the East Coast of the U.S. is how to say, ""No."", and to enjoy doing so with sadistic pleasure . Basically, had I not learned to say, ""No."", few would have had any qualms about taking advantage of my life. Although I am not Black, I am a woman of color, and did not want to incur more disapproval than my abusive mother had taught me that I already deserved by existing. So, learning to say no was an uphill battle, but I can't recommend it highly enough. * * * One thing I learned during my cancer treatment is that I fvcking loathe incompetent, lazy healthcare 'professionals' and would rather die than become a ward of the state, or enter the 'care' of a nursing hom
e ( https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/09/us/vegetative-state-birth-woman.html ). An online search for: 'nursing home woman raped' makes me eat right and work out. I need to fill out a DNR and an Advance Directive. * * * Although I think such a thread already exists in this forum, it might be a good idea to actively maintain it, regarding country- and state-wide end-of-life considerations for the solitary (unfortunately, a bomb has to be lit under my rss to even grocery shop or I'd do it). Web pages to that effect probably already exist."
174333491,Yes even if have no mental disease. AP should only be taken if have positive symptoms which cannot be controlled by the individual. If a normal person is drugged with AP for certain period and if AP suddenly stopped they experience positive symptoms for some period and some time it can become permanent and then require AP to manage positive symptoms. Also if a normal person is drugged with AP they can experience mild negative symptoms due to the dopamine blocking effect.

174333506,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov Insight and medication adherence in schizophrenia: An analysis of the CATIE data. _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _NAME_, A _PERSON_ and _PERSON_, Neuropharmacology , May 2019 08 Adherence to antipsychotic medication is critical for the treatment of patients with schizophrenia. Impaired insight into illness is one of the principal drivers of medication nonadherence, which contributes to negative clinical outcomes. The aims of this study were to examine the relationships between impaired insight and (1) rates of antipsychotic mediation nonadherence, and (2) time to medication nonadherence using data from the Clinical Antipsychotic Trials of Intervention Effectiveness (CATIE). Insight was assessed using the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) item G12 (lack of judgment and insight). Patients were divided into 3 groups based on their degree of insight impairment, i.e. no impairment (PANSS G12?=?1), minimal impairment (PANSS G12?=?2-3), and moderate
-to-severe insight impairment (PANSS G12???4). Medication nonadherence was defined as taking less than 80% of monthly pill counts. _PERSON_ survival and _PERSON_ regression analyses were performed to examine differences in time to medication nonadherence between insight groups. There were significant group differences in the percentage of nonadherent patients at 6 months (?2(2)?=?8.80, p?=?0.012) and 18 months (?2(2)?=?10.04, p?=?0.007) after study initiation. Moderate-to-severe insight impairment was associated with earlier nonadherence compared to minimal (?2?=?4.70, p?=?0.030) or no impairment (?2?=?11.92, p?=?0.001). The association remained significant after adjustment for illness severity, substance use, attitudes toward medication, cognition, level of hostility, and depression. The results of this study indicate a strong link between impaired insight and antipsychotic medication adherence. Intervention studies targeted to enhance insight may help improve medication adherence, and in turn, other clinica
l outcomes in patients with schizophrenia."

175921147,"(This same response by _NAME_ to _PERSON_ question about Lexicpro side effects is on both threads: 1. “Lexipro (or other SSRI’s) and Muscle Twitching” 2. and “Left pectoral muscle twitches” Michael85 is on two Anxiety forum threads (“Lexipro (or other SSRI’s) and Muscle Twitching” and “Left pectoral muscle twitches”). I’ve had muscle twitching also and did not connect it to medicine for 5 years. But the twitching was connected to a medicine I was taking (Mirtazapine anti-depressant). Net says Mirtazapine is an SSRI which “stands for Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor. SSRI antidepressants are a type of antidepressant that work by increasing levels of serotonin within the brain. Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that is often referred to as the `feel good hormone'”. So when the question arises, does (“Lexipro (or other SSRI’s) [cause] Muscle Twitching” I found the answer to be, yes, Lexipro and other SSRI’s can cause muscle twitching. This is of interest to me bec
ause I take an SSRI (Mirtazapine) and I have muscle twitching. I have taken that medicine for five years. For the first 3 years (taking 15 mg.), I made no connection between taking the Mirtazapine at 12 midinight, and by toes starting to twitch 30-45 minutes later, plus my appetite increasing to where I had to get up and have a snack. Due to circumstances, the connection dawned on me and my psychiatrist reduced the med to 7.5 from 15 mg and I thought all was taken care of. For the last 2 years on 7.5 mg, I would have occasional toe twitching but it has increased, followed by getting up and having another snack. So I get to bed at 12 midnight, and at 5 a.m. I have yet to get to sleep. Two days ago for the first time, I connected all of that, so I took my Mirtazapine not at midnight, but 5 hours earlier at 7 p.m., hoping the side effects would wear off at midnight, and they did and I slept from 12 midnight to 8 a.m.. about the SSRI Lexapro (treats anxiety and depression net says), Webmd.com says under rare side 
effects: A Feeling Of Restlessness With Inability To Sit Still Muscle Tremors Cramps And under “Side Effects, 5th paragraph: “twitching muscles”. By clicking on “twitching muscles” in the 5th paragraph of Side Effects, it said: ""Twitches. Unlike tics, the majority of muscle twitches are isolated occurrences, not repeated actions. Muscle twitches are also known as myoclonic jerks. They are entirely involuntary and cannot be controlled or suppressed."" So I would say SSRI’s can cause twitching muscles. You also said, “Recently, and even before going back on the Lexapro (after being off of that for 8 months), I’ve had the annoying and worrisome twitches and spasm in my left breast muscle.” Trying to figure out what to do after finding out the SSRI’s can cause muscle twitching I’m finding to also be a problem. I’m trying to take my Mirtazapine 5 hours early. But the twitching toes starts only about an hour or two after taking the medicine, so I maybe I can take it 2 hours before bedtime. 
You might also use a heating pad as a combination approach to working on this issue of muscle twitching. Anyway, that’s the situation as I see it."

175921152,"For sleep, I take Melatonin from the health food store, although it may be sold in drug stores and grocery stores in the health food section. It's not a doctor medication so I don't consider it a drug. However, I also take Lithium stabilizer and Mirtazapine anti-depressant, since I'm bipolar. Without taking those two meds, and just by taking a Melatonin or two, I'm not going to sleep. With emotional issues, like bipolar, I need doctor meds to take care of that. Then, if I can't sleep, the Melatonin might and does help. So, if you're going to wing it without meds with your anxiety attacks, that also might include side issues such as sleepless nights. As they say, the lack of sleep may not be the main problem, it could be only a sign of something deeper, like anxiety attacks. If you decide you're not going to treat the anxiety attacks, you're probably not going to be able to treat the sleep problem with _NAME_ food products. I've been off meds and tried to treat my sleep problem with a health food it
em and it didn't work. You may find different. As for Melatonin, I take 4 (1 mg) an hour or more before bedtime, 1 at bedtime, and if I wake up at 3 a.m. and can't get back to sleep, I might take another one. (Although some Melatonin now comes with extended release, meaning it can slowly release over hours of time. I've had anxiety attacks and once it breaks free in your brain, it seems to set up a pattern for it to occur again. My 1st anxiety attack was from being treated with an antipsychotic med for my bipolar that did not suit me at all. My 2nd group of anxiety attacks was from being treated only for depression when what I really had was manic depression. The anti-depressant alone (with no stabilizer like Lithium which I now take) pushed me into mania and anxiety attacks. Since Lithium was added to the anti-depressant, I've had no more anxiety attacks in 25 years. I think there is a correlation. Medicine has side affects but not taking medicine can have side affects also. You're experiencing two of those.

175921168,"True. If you've not read it, I'd suggest you read ""Man's Search for Meaning,"" by _PERSON_. It's a relatively short book that outlines how the Jewish psychologist endured through the Nazi concentration camps during WWII. He lost his whole family but came out of the process to develop a new therapy method that would change the way therapy worked. It's main message is that of choice, but you need to have something to choose to find that way forward, which is what his therapy seeks to uncover. I think the biggest problems are not the most severe; they're the relatively common ones that just keep going, as they become exhausting. You constantly see people who go through massive trauma, losing limbs, acute illness etc, and they come out of the other end determined to climb a mountain or whatever, fighting for a cause. You can focus on that; there's a seen 'enemy' and a way forward. The sort of problems that seem to disable people psychologically are the ones where there is no time-frame and no fixing t
he issue. _PERSON_ made the observation that the prisoners who had family who were killed actually survived better than the ones who had no family to start with. There was a focus for their pain. Lack of cash, chronic pain, unemployment, poor living conditions, etc., they're not dramatic enough to get sympathy from others and there's no end in sight."

175921173,"I think I did not put it clearly. You speak of questioning whether intersubjective reality is real or has a basis in fact. All examples that explicate the meaning of what is called ‘real’ or ‘fact’ come from intersubjective reality. Hence, to use such terms to question it is a case of pragmatic self-defeat. Unless you can explicate a different meaning for the terms used."

175921181,"TAK-041, a GPR139 agonist for anhedonia GPR139 (G protein-coupled receptor 139) is a protein that in humans is encoded by the GPR139 gene. GPR139 is an orphan G-protein–coupled receptor expressed in the central nervous system. The expression pattern of GPR139 has primarily been studied on the mRNA level and showed expression mainly in the central nervous system. GPR139 is an orphan receptor identified from bioinformatics analysis of the human genome. GPR139 is thus a potential target for the treatment of Parkinson’s disease, obesity, eating disorders, and/or diabetes. The GPR139 is expressed specifically in the brain in areas of relevance for motor control. GPR139 function and signal transduction pathways are elusive, and results in the literature are even contradictory. GPR139 agonists dose-dependently protect primary dopaminergic (DA) neurons against MPP+ toxicity."

175921189,"As someone who has studied various spiritualities for years and studies under a teacher of mysticism, I think it all comes down to the same point: “you have control of your mind”. Hallucinations, if focused in a spiritual direction, can increase your awe of the universe and gratitude to be in it, but the most important part of a spiritual practice should ultimately be how to benefit those you love and the world at large. If hallucinations make this difficult, they should be ignored and blocked. Otherwise, nothing on our beautiful Earth will change. 175921248,"If you are looking to find the physical brain disorder, one that can be treated, and usually to the point of cure, while also being an infection that mainstream medicine will not currently acknowledge, consider Lyme. 3M people a year get it in the US, most without initially noticing, and since most are rarely diagnosed we have ongoing infections that average about a third of US Americans will be infected in our lifetimes. You want to find out early because it can progress quickly and stubbornly and be expensive. At any rate, I am experiencing anxiety lately which I don't have much of a history of until the last few years. I had cleared up a Bartonella infection and then this Babesia red blood cell brain infection then grew like a new infection. Mostly I experience anxiety, fatigue, brain fog, brain pressure and sometimes odd but not particularly painful brain sensations. There are half a dozen diseases you can get from a tick and they are collectively called Lyme. I hope this helps and if it does, 
please come back and help others."

175921277,"en.m.wikipedia.org Introspection illusion The introspection illusion is a cognitive bias in which people wrongly think they have direct insight into the origins of their mental states, while treating others' introspections as unreliable. In certain situations, this illusion leads people to make confident but false explanations of their own behaviour (called ""causal theories"") or inaccurate predictions of their future mental states. The illusion has been examined in psychological experiments, and suggested as a basis for biases in how pe..."

175921278,"Typically, we like to leave inactive threads alone and just start a new thread instead. This is different than how some forums are run, but we do it this way because it frequently upsets users to have old topics revived when they are no longer relevant. It can also be frustrating to the person who revived the thread when they don’t get a reply, because the original poster is no longer active or no longer finds the topic relevant. Feel free to start a new thread on this topic. Thanks, Volunteer Moderator _AT_MENTION_"

175921310,"They put those dates on medicine for a reason. The drugs might be lose their potency if they’re too old. Also, it’s conceivable that they might “turn bad” and possibly poison or harm you in some way if they’re too old. Also, one certain AP may stay useable longer than some other AP. i.e. 5 year old risperidone may still be effective while 3 year old prolixen may not work. Those are just theoretical, random examples. But yeah, old pills might harm you in some way but I don’t know for sure."

174333554,"There are many actual objective reasons behind the repeated failure to design a successful treatment capable of achieving recovery or complete elimination of symptoms ,because there is a serious error repeated in the data content of all causal and medical theories relating to the nature of the condition of what is schizophrenia,which leads to intuition of what is the cause of the sz that must be treated Look at the serious error committed during dissection the properties of things called the symptoms of sz ( according to the external observer’s observations), They are divided into negative,positive and cognitive deficiency The characteristics of structure /function of the pathogen (hallucinations personalities), which supposed to be classified as the existential and functional cause of the sz condition, unexpected,all therapeutic theories treat the pathogen itself as a one of the symptom of the sz case OR as a result of sz In practice,it means changing the main positions of the condition’s subs
tances by putting the pathogen itself with the results in one position , Whereas,it is impossible to treat the pathogen as it is a result of the sz case (as a one of its symptoms) by any classical medication methods Because,the sz pathogen corresponds to a gene or a virus,cannot by treated with the current conventional methods of treatment, which requires an autoimmune antigen or a method capable of inducing a change in the basic structure or replacement…etc When treating the pathogen (hallucination) as a symptom of sz,the conventional treatment will fail in treating the pathogen ,and the opportunity will persist for all symptoms to occur with any degree of severity at any time / circumstance Most symptoms do not disappear completely and remain present to some degree and inherent to the presence of pathogen due to their association with it causally ! all current medical methods,it is a means of inhibiting interactive responses in the person (receptors) With excessive activity of the pathogen for a wile (4 w
eeks-for example),which is the sufficient time to forming,creating or development of self-immune soldiers in order to activate the state of chemical balance in the existence of the pathogen without need to external medical intervention"

174333557,"The schizophrenia condition which represented in the hallucinations is a factor of change (the mutational factor itself) -It is autonomous non-rooted by the human functions of the genetic material -The sz condition arises ontologically due to the functions of its independent factor (H) -Sz condition or its symptoms does not arise from pathological mutation that occur in the inherited biological system -Likewise,sz does not cause pathological changes in the inherited “existing / current” biological system The biological nature remains in its basic position that it was created or it has been existed on it since its initial inception,no change occurs in the inherited structure / function Means,before,during and after the onset of sz,there is absolutely NO cellular,chemical or functional change in the inherited biological system regardless the existence of any mental disorders or chemical imbalance In other words,there is no form of sustained pathological changes occurring in the genetic material l
ike what is happens in the genetic diseases Because,the mutational factor (hallucinations) is an external factor that is not a part from the genetic material or even the psychological self itself ,it is a Parasite in the same position of the virus or bacteria it means,all symptoms of sz does not arise by action of a defective gene,anatomy,chemical or function self-origin at all ,rather they are arise as a final result of the effectiveness of the mutational factor (H) on the higher mental processes on the level of the cognitive concept and kinetic pathways of the transmitters / receptors Ask me ,how do you prove these facts ?"

174333558,"For starters, it’s saying sugar doesn’t cause inflammation, when studies show it does. Curcumin doesn’t lower the inflammation marker TBARS very much, so it might not be a useful anti-inflammatory. And it’s true that chronic inflammation isn’t the outright cause of much illness, like it just happened in a vacuum, there’s a whole pathology of bad habits leading up to it. It’s just a treatable illness vector. For instance, with mental illnesses like schizophrenia, a weak blood-brain barrier is typically the cause of chronic brain inflammation, and healing the BBB offers a more permanent solution rather than taking mass anti-inflammatories."

174333596,"Well, you may recover and get better. But it’s not easy to ignore schizophrenia. And it’s hard to get to a place where it doesn’t affect you at all. Who really knows how it will affect you 2, 5, or 10 years down the road? It may get better it may get worse. I don’t want to be discouraging but the disease can be a lifelong affliction for many. I don’t know about your recovery personally but it’s possible to work while having schizophrenia. You may have to set your sites lower to accommodate the disease, i.e. instead of being the head prosecutor arguing felony charges in court in front of a judge you may have to be the clerk at the desk helping the people file cases in an office. Instead of being the paramedic rushing all over the city at night saving peoples lives you may have to be the security guard opening the gate for the ambulance to get inside to drop people off at the E.R. Goals are great within reason. I hate to be negative but even someone with schizophrenia has to see certain r
ealities. But on the bright side who knows? Hell, anyone looking at me at age 19-21 when I first got sick and I was at my worst would never have imagined I would ever work again or go to school or drive again or live independently. But I did all those things. For years. And at age 59 I’m still doing them. I never had the glamorous jobs but the jobs I’ve had put gas in the car, good food on the table, kept me in nice clothes, paid for my entertainment, allowed me to buy many luxuries over the years, kept me in comfortable warm housing and pay all the miscellaneous expenses that occasionally come up in a persons life i.e. car insurance, registration for my car, replacing a faulty laptop, etc. So yeah, life is a gamble at best but I came from nothing but ended up doing lots of decent, fun things in life. And an important bonus is that I’m personally not a bad guy in everyday life. People give me friendly looks all the time, strangers judge me occasionally and see that I mean well and smile. I don’t hurt 
or bother anyone for the most part and I get to occasionally help people IRL. So yeah, you can accomplish something, we see it all the time on these very boards. I hope your brother was trying to help you and not hurt you but he may be partially correct, It’s no reason to give up or quit though. He may be right but he’s not a doctor or a fortune teller. Life is funny and full of surprises, sometimes great stuff happens to us out of the blue. I wish you good luck."
174333600,"I read those other news stories online and they came up when my mindset was in anger. I didn’t even consider that paraphrasing to be a threat but more of a warning. The co-worker that I threatened didn’t conclude or comprehend what message I was trying to convey to him because he said, “What’s your point?” I rarely get angry and in particular I shouldn’t be getting angry at work because I do not deal with customers. I just lift boxes and tie them up. At that time, I wasn’t even thinking about the schizophrenia forum at all because I was caught in the moment. Your example with the audiologist and secretary doesn’t compare to the details I have left out in this thread. It’s more complicated and involves a vast group of people which I haven’t included."

Most drugs can’t go to the brain."

Despite being widely used as a sleep aid due its sedating effect, the benefits of such use do not appear to generally outweigh the side effects. It is taken by mouth. Common side effects include sleepiness, constipation, weight gain, and dry mouth. Other side effects include low blood pressure with standin..."

174333606,"I found it interesting that this research identified a possible physical / organic cause of schizophrenia which is in complete contrast to how schizophrenia is currently diagnosed. The present method of diagnosis relies upon the patient’s disclosure of symptoms, the symptoms being descriptions of various experiences of consciousness. I think the main reason there is so much _USER_ID_ associated with schizophrenia is because it is described as a “mental” illness instead of being what it is… A brain disease that involves gradual loss of brain cells over time and organic abnormalities such as described in this research. If more people realized that schizophrenia is a brain disease then there would be less _USER_ID_ and greater support for finding a cure."

175921565,"From Medscape: COVID-19 and psychosis: is there a link? Since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, most of the research into the SARS-CoV-2 virus has focused on its direct effects on the body with the aim of finding effective treatments and, ultimately, a cure. However, researchers _NAME_, PhD, and _NAME_, MD, are investigating a potential secondary, long-term impact of COVID-19 exposure — greater susceptibility to psychosis. “Over the years there have been data showing an association between exposure to general respiratory viruses such as the flu and subsequent psychotic episodes. This association was especially evident in studies of the aftermath of the great influenza of 1918,” _PERSON_, assistant professor of pediatrics, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Maryland, told Medscape Medical News . Against this background, the investigators conducted a 2011 study to determine “whether or not this association with psychosis was specific to influenza, or if other respiratory infections like t
he coronavirus might also have similar consequences,” said Severance. The researchers examined the response of immunoglobulin G against four human coronavirus strains common at the time. Results showed that more than 90% of adults diagnosed with psychoses had high levels of antibodies to one or more of the viruses, and that all four coronaviruses were more seroprevalent in patients versus controls. Multivariate analyses suggested that two of the coronaviruses — HKU1 and NL63 — may confer particular risk for neuropsychiatric disease. The current study will build on these earlier findings. The researchers plan to examine adult case-control comparisons of the four less severe coronaviruses (229E, NL63, OC43, HKU1) and quantify the seroprevalence of the more severe forms of the virus, MERS, SARS-CoV-1, and SARS-CoV-2, in patients with psychiatric disorders versus controls"

175921568,"Doctors almost always start with the lowest therapeutic dose and work up. It’s known as titration. So don’t worry if you don’t get immediate results. Finding the right drug at the right dose is more art than science. During this period find a way to journal your emotional state. It doesn’t have to be extensive. Heck, add an emoji or two on a calendar. As long as you can recall enough to tell your doctor. It’ll help determine if you’re on the right path. And Zoloft has been a mainstay prescription for years. There’s little to be concerned about. Hang in there."

175921595,"Ignore the voice. Move on without responding to it. Let the voice be there but not respond to it. It only becomes a problem if you start believing in it, responding to it. Consider it like some barking dog, crow sound etc. You can re tune the voice in some mickey mouse voice to make it so unappealing, funny. Can add some circus music to it etc."

175921601,"All three of my stays in psych ward were involuntary. The food was really nice and last place I was at they let me crewchette which made it less boring once I was starting to feel better. I really liked the people I think. There were some really nice people in hospital. Some were not nice and some were violent. One girl threw a glass of water on my face because I stole her seat at dinner she said that’s where she sits. One guy and a male nurse got in a fist fight right next to me and another nurse came and pushed me into safety. Once I remember wanting to go to hospital. That was when I stopped taking olanzapine and was getting worse. I felt unable to take care of myself. I could not feed myself and I could not hydrate myself and do normal things like personal care shower. I finally took a sleeping tablet and started tak
ing olanzapine again and immediately (overnight) became better. I wanted to go to hospital because I knew I was getting worse and I felt unable to take care of myself and was having delusions and feeling psychotic. I even had my bag packed ready to take myself in but took medication instead and it helped. In Sweden they had a daycare kind of place where you could go to do pottery and sewing ,woodwork etc and then they had work groups and made things that were sold and I joined a work group that worked at a cafe in a retirement home. It was really good but unfortunately they don’t gave it anymore. The bad thing is there was no invetween for those that were not well enough to be in the work groups there should have been other options where they could come and go for as long as they feel up to . I understand the feeling of needing help with daily living sometimes not coping and then thought of a care home or assisted living . 174333624,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov Cardiac structure and function in schizophrenia: cardiac magnetic resonance imaging study. _PERSON_, SP _PERSON_, A _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, A _PERSON_, _PERSON_ Cook, _NAME_ and _PERSON_, The British journal of psychiatry : the journal of mental science , Jan 2020 09 Heart disease is the leading cause of death in schizophrenia. However, there has been little research directly examining cardiac function in schizophrenia.To investigate cardiac structure and function in individuals with schizophrenia using cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (CMR) after excluding medical and metabolic comorbidity.In total, 80 participants underwent CMR to determine biventricular volumes and function and measures of blood pressure, physical activity and glycated haemoglobin levels. Individuals with schizophrenia ('patients') and controls were matched for age, gender, ethnicity and body surface area.Patients had significantly smaller indexed left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic v
olume (effect size d = -0.82, P = 0.001), LV end-systolic volume (d = -0.58, P = 0.02), LV stroke volume (d = -0.85, P = 0.001), right ventricular (RV) end-diastolic volume (d = -0.79, P = 0.002), RV end-systolic volume (d = -0.58, P = 0.02), and RV stroke volume (d = -0.87, P = 0.001) but unaltered ejection fractions relative to controls. LV concentricity (d = 0.73, P = 0.003) and septal thickness (d = 1.13, P < 0.001) were significantly larger in the patients. Mean concentricity in patients was above the reference range. The findings were largely unchanged after adjusting for smoking and/or exercise levels and were independent of medication dose and duration.Individuals with schizophrenia show evidence of concentric cardiac remodelling compared with healthy controls of a similar age, gender, ethnicity, body surface area and blood pressure, and independent of smoking and activity levels. This could be contributing to the excess cardiovascular mortality observed in schizophrenia. Future studies should investi
gate the contribution of antipsychotic medication to these changes."

175921648,"journals.plos.org The Antipsychotic Olanzapine Interacts with the Gut Microbiome to Cause... The second-generation antipsychotic olanzapine is effective in reducing psychotic symptoms but can cause extreme weight gain in human patients. We investigated the role of the gut microbiota in this adverse drug effect using a mouse model. First, we... I think antipsychotics can affect the bacteria in our gut in a way that makes us gain weight more easily. This is at least the case in second generation antipsychotics so not sure about haldol, but I reckon it is the case for haldol too, just my gut instinct. For this reason I purposely eat stricter. Since it’s harder to lose weight. Idk if there is a med for it. I personally wouldn’t go on a weight loss med."

174333629,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov Positive effects of systemic sodium benzoate and olanzapine treatment on activities of daily life, spatial learning and working memory in ketamine-induced rat model of schizophrenia. GS _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_ and _PERSON_, International journal of physiology, pathophysiology and pharmacology , 2019 Sodium Benzoate (SB) significantly improved positive, negative, and cognitive symptoms as add on treatment in schizophrenia. Olanzapine (_NAME_), the most effective atypical antipsychotic drug, has been linked to hepatic steatosis, acute kidney injury, reproductive side effects and poor effect on negative symptoms in some patients.is to compare the efficacy and check the safety of long-term monotherapy with SB 0.01 mg/Kg versus _NAME_ on male cognitive, memory, hepatic, renal and testicular functions in rat model of schizophrenia.48 young adult male rats were divided into 6 groups; C: control; O: received _NAME_; SB: received SB; K: received single IP ketamine (Ket) injection; K+O: 
received _NAME_ and Ket and K+SB: received SB and Ket. _NAME_ and SB given orally for 3 or 10 weeks for behavioral or serological studies respectively. We measured activities of daily life (ADL), spatial learning and memory in radial arm water maze (RAWM), serum parameters of hepatic, renal and testicular functions.Both _NAME_ and SB significantly improved hoarding and burrowing, caused significant decrease in time to reach target (TRT), working memory errors (WME) in K+O and K+SB groups compared to K group. _NAME_ caused significant increase in ALT, AST and creatinine and decrease in serum LH, testosterone compared to controls. SB caused significant rise in serum LH, ALT, AST and decrease in protein and albumin compared to both C and O groups.Both _NAME_ and SB improved ADL, cognitive and memory functions. Although SB saved testicular and renal functions, it worsened liver function compared to _NAME_."

175921700,"I got tmg supplements about a month ago. I started taking 500mg once in the morning. Sadly, after 3 days I developed a chronic headache. I decided not to take anymore and left it for a few days. Then after a few days I decided (as I was just about to throw the supplement in the bin) that I would try them one more time. Well, I’m glad I did. I took another 500mg and waited to see if I got a headache. Sadly, I did get another headache, but this time it wasn’t so intense. So I thought I’d stick with for a few more days to see if the headache subsided even more…and it did, the headache was much less intense. So I carried on taking the supplement for more days, and to my surprise, the headache was not there. I wondered why this happened. So I researched betaine and found out it detoxes your liver and body. Maybe that’s why I got these horrendous headaches? I also found out beetroot’s detoxify your liver and body. To my surprise, beetroots contain the highest amount of betaine/tmg. I honestly 
wasn’t even searching about betaine in beetroot, it was just coincidence. So I bought beetroot from my grocery and now add them to smoothies and salad sandwiches and burgers. I also take the betaine supplement as well. I don’t over do it though. I like it a lot. When I first took it I feel I was hyper focused to the point of migraine headaches. Now I’m focused more, but without the headache. It’s been nearly a month I think. I’m gonna see how I feel later in the year. So all in all I give it a thumbs up."

175921714,"I have this problem with the way that I think. I’ve tried to describe it to a doctor and a therapist and neither had anything to say about it. My thoughts used to flow freely, quietly, and naturally. Now they are less “thought like” and more like me talking to myself inside my head. For example, in the past I might have seen rain and automatically grabbed an umbrella. Now I see rain and have to say in my head, I need to go get an umbrella. Like all the words in a complete sentence. And that’s how all my thoughts are these days. Me speaking complete sentences in my head. If I try not to do it, it’s like I completely stop processing information until I start talking out loud in my head again. It’s really exhausting. Plus it makes me a really slow and inefficient thinker. Also, it has nothing to do with medication."

174333641,"Genetic causes are not reversible. Maybe 1% get back to normal and their cause is drugs like weed (They stop the drug, they get back normal) but many, 15% according to wikipedia, are able to work. 85% are unemployed, which is mostly genetic causes and some are homeless or in mental hospital. I am not able to work, I have a major university degree in physiotherapy and I worked a week in a gym at more than double the minimum wage, I was stressed because I was surrounded by people and I quit. I quit 15 different jobs and I quit forever now. The issue is not scientific intelligence but people and social intelligence. I took 4 Psychology courses in my university after my disease and I got 3 A’s and 1 B. My teacher told me if I wanted to switch my degree to psychology because I was in the top 5 in my classes. I can continue my studies and get a PhD now but for what if I can’t work, interact with people and function in society? I know 2 schizophrenic twins, same genes, one got his PhD in engineering a

175921794,"I partially agree with you. I believe the moments of happiness, when you’re conscious of it, and can bask in it, that’s what makes the tough times worth it. 175921795,"Sometimes getting sober is not a matter of “feeling good” or “feeling happy”. Sometimes it’s more like not feeling bad anymore. And if you stay sober there’s a good chance that your general quality of life will improve. Two weeks is commendable. Congratulations. But you’re still in the early stages of sobriety. Don’t expect miracles, give it time; the rewards will come. I couldn’t put a specific time frame on when those rewards will come. For me personally, when I first got clean and sober I became employed and went to college within the first couple months. I left the addict lifestyle behind and only hung around other clean and sober people. I stopped hanging around people who used drugs or drank and stopped going to places where drugs and alcohol were being used. The rewards for me were many and 31 years later I can look back on getting clean as one of the best things I’ve done in life."

175921881,"It might not be the meds. Sometimes our brains can sort of turn emotions and reactions off. It’s almost impossible for me to show anger and even feel anger. Growing up I was essentially taught you dont get angry my brain grew up with this and it now has that inability to show anger. I start to get angry and itll just disappear. Same thing goes for crying around others. As for a solution that will be something hat mainly you’ll have to play around with, everyone is different. I used to journal a lot. Writer down every single thought, every single emotion. Sometimes I would cry. Sometimes I wouldnt. But a lot of the time I felt lighter than before. Paper holds emotions a lot better than humans. I would do art. Sometimes I didnt know what to draw so I would just scribble I would scribble the whole page and it’s weird but I would feel better. I would listen to songs that I could relate to, songs about things I was going through. It helped me feel less alone and for whatever reason it opened that 
emotional trap and let me cry. Sometimes I would write poems, other times i would come up with random verses to songs that would never get a finished tune. Sometimes i would just curl up under a blanket and just let myself feel. I would try to not shut down. Sometimes it would help to talk to somebody, they wouldnt even really need to say anything. It was good to just have somebody that would listen."

174333713,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov The effect of mind-body and aerobic exercise on negative symptoms in schizophrenia: A _NAME_-analysis. _PERSON_, _NAME_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_ and _PERSON_, Psychiatry research, 2019 09 This _NAME_-analysis aims to evaluate the effects of different types of physical exercise (PE) on negative symptoms in schizophrenia patients. Mind-body exercise (MBE), aerobic exercise (AE) and resistance training (RT) will be investigated.The Cochrane Library, Medline, Embase and PsycINFO were searched from their inception until April 26, 2018. Randomized controlled trials comparing PE with any control group in patients with schizophrenia were included when negative symptoms had been assessed. This _NAME_-analysis was conducted according to the PRISMA guidelines. The methodological quality of the included studies was assessed with the Cochrane Risk of Bias assessment tool. Moderator, sensitivity, and _NAME_ regression analyses were conducted to explore causes of heterogeneity and impact of 
study quality.We included 22 studies (N?=?1249). The overall methodological quality was poor. The _NAME_-analysis (random effects model) showed a medium significant effect in favor of any PE intervention (_PERSON_ g?=?0.434, 95% CI = 0.196-0.671) versus any control condition. MBE and AE respectively showed a medium significant effect (Hedges' g?=?0.461) and a small significant effect (Hedges' g?=?0.341) versus any control condition. The effect of RT could not be examined. The overall heterogeneity was high (I2 = 76%) and could not be reduced with moderator or sensitivity analyses.This _NAME_-analysis demonstrated that PE could be a promising intervention in the treatment of negative symptoms. However, the quality of the included studies was low and heterogeneity was high, which makes it impossible to make a clear recommendation. Therefore, results should be interpreted with care."

174333748,"Moderate Interaction Be cautious with this combination ! Medications changed by the liver (Cytochrome P450 1A2 (CYP1A2) substrates) interacts with SULFORAPHANE Some medications are changed and broken down by the liver. Sulforaphane might decrease how quickly the liver breaks down some medications. Taking sulforaphane along with some medications that are changed by the liver might increase the effects and side effects of some medications. Before taking sulforaphane talk to your healthcare provider if you take any medications that are changed by the liver. Some medications that are changed by the liver include clozapine (Clozaril), cyclobenzaprine (Flexeril), fluvoxamine (Luvox), haloperidol (Haldol), imipramine (Tofranil), mexiletine (Mexitil), olanzapine (Zyprexa), pentazocine (Talwin), propranolol (Inderal), tacrine (Cognex), theophylline, zileuton (Zyflo), zolmitriptan (Zomig), and others."

175922260,"Hi _AT_MENTION_. Typically, we like to leave inactive threads alone and just start a new thread instead. This is different than how some forums are run, but we do it this way because it frequently upsets users to have old topics revived when they are no longer relevant. It can also be frustrating to the person who revived the thread when they don’t get a reply, because the original poster is no longer active or no longer finds the topic relevant. Feel free to start a new thread on this topic. Thanks, _AT_MENTION_ Volunteer Moderator"

175922300,"I think we are operating under different ideas of what self-motivation is. To me, it is the beliefe that you can accomplish a goal combined with taking actions to achieve that goal. To you, it is the ability to not get exhausted and feel defeated. I can guarantee you I feel exhausted and defeated a lot of the time. I have days where it feels impossible to get off the couch. I have days where I think I will never be neurotypical, so thereis no point in trying. I would even say most days I feel this way. But I force myself to do at least one thing every day. Once I’ve taken the first step of starting a task, it is easier to carry on doing tasks. You think that people like me don’t experience negatives. I can tell you, I very much do. I will avoid showering until Mr. Star literally kicks me out of bed because I smell. I will look at the messy house and be parlyized with the inability to clean for hours and days. I will fall into a depressive episode and have incredible difficulty pulling myself of
f the couch. I have learned, over time and in specialized therapies, how to compensate for these defecits so they don’t continue to ruin my life."

174333775,"I was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia in 1985, and I still have symptoms of the illness. Overall, I think my symptoms have improved, but I attribute that, for the most part, to my environment improving. It’s a long story, but my environment improved greatly in 2012. I also entered into a relationship that year and got a pet (my first pet at age 48). And I started taking care of my mother (who is very sick now (she was living with my sister)). So for the first time in my life I had to care about someone/something other than myself. I still feel uncomfortable going outside of my house (I have this feeling that people are looking/judging me), and I have difficulty taking a shower. I don’t think I’ll ever be comfortable doing certain things, so I have to push myself, no way around it. I’ve become comfortable being uncomfortable; I have to embrace the suck. That’s okay, because that’s where the growth happens."

175922320,I’m on SSDI. I tried working full time and couldn’t support myself. I had gotten off my benefits but when I couldn’t work full time I got back on them. So maybe you could call and ask Social Security what would happen if you tried working full time but didn’t succeed. Because I was told that Social Security will keep your case on their rolls for awhile so that if you need it again they will automatically reinstate you without having to go through the whole process of starting over from scratch and having to start the process of getting benefits from the very beginning. 175922337,"Someone wrote this already but AA has some pretty good advice. When you feel those cravings and you want to drink, play it through in your mind. Picture the whole process of what’s going to happen if you drink. If you have one beer , it will lead to another. You may feel good for a short while but you will want more and you’ll feel bad afterwards. You will regret it and probably beat yourself up for giving in. You will have the remorse that you gave in. If you are trying to quit for good you will run into temptation occasionally. You have to figure out what will work to successfully fight that temptation. That is what AA is good for. If you join AA you will always have a support system. AA members don’t mind giving out their phone numbers to each other so that you don’t have to fight the urges to drink alone. Help and support is available 24/7."

175922346,"All I know is that they are the best option we have right now. I trust there will be better options in the future. My aunt who had schiz went off her meds. There are better medications in the works that don’t focus as heavily on dopamine, you can search for their names online. Until they are out we have to be patient. I feel grateful I have a decent medication to be on, while looking forward to better ones in the future. I use vitamins and exercise to increase neuronal connectivity. 175922365,"I was still typing and hit the done button before I was done. So now there’s 2 replies. I think *most* people don’t understand the inner experiences of those with mental health conditions. Maybe they see some of the outward signs (though not always). Then there is what they see on the media, which is of course stigmatized. But *most* people don’t understand the inner experiences. Because of a lack of understanding, in some cases people say insensitive things. (An example is telling a person with depression their life is good so they should just be happy). The comments people are making to you about them “being so ocd” are kind of similar, imo, in that they’re insensitive and also show a lack of understanding. I point these things out NOT as an excuse for others, but because I see it as a contributing factor to the problem being discussed."

175922390,"At 10 years, 46.2% (n = 140 of 303) of patients achieved symptom recovery and 40.9% (n = 117) achieved functional recovery. The strongest predictor of symptom recovery at 10 years was symptom remission at 12 weeks (adj OR 4.47; CI 2.60–7.67); followed by a diagnosis of depression with psychotic symptoms (adj OR 2.68; CI 1.02–7.05). Symptom remission at 12 weeks was also a strong predictor of functional recovery at 10 years."

175922399,"The thing is, life still isn’t over. You always have the option to make different choices today than you made yesterday. My family wasn’t speaking to me until 2015. 175922446,"I believe the lack of thoughts or inability to think clearly or hold multiple thoughts in mind have something to do with sleep quality. Sleep deprivation can causes various side effects both immediately and in long run. Try to improve the sleep, if hard to get good sleep at night try taking some long nap like 1 hr nap before 4 pm. Blunted affect can also be improved with quality sleep. Many medications and supplements can affect sleep for example omega 3, vitamin b12, liones mane mushroom etc try to avoid or reduce to improve sleep quality. Caffeine beverages can affect sleep if take later part of day."

175922460,Please be careful on recommending supplements. It’s easy to read on the internet that this or that works or doesn’t. Rarely do such things go through double blind studies. Please provide links or such when recommending supplements so at least we can get a handle on what is going on. It’s important to provide protection for members here and just because you read things on the internet doesn’t make things scientifically viable nor does it make it something that works for all. Medications are hit or miss. Why should supplements be anything but if even that? Please provide current publications or articles.

174333819,Hi _AT_MENTION_. My psychiatrist says I have an unusually high level of insight into my schizophrenia. My insight started to develop about 2 or 3 years after I was diagnosed and medicated. Hallucinations and delusions create a patchwork like fused consciousness stream with unsubstantiated unreal segments merged in between real accurately perceived segments. As insight starts to develop you start to recognize which segment of your consciousness stream is real and which is unreal or being played for you like audio or video coming from your mind. Insight builds on itself. The more you come to recognize what is real and not real the more you come to recognize what is real and not real. Best of everything on your journey to wellness.

175922529,"So here is my story. I am a male, 29, from India. Back in 2009 when I was about to graduate high school, my world turned upside down within a matter of days and it became more & more hellish as days went by. At that time I could not understand what is happening, but today I realize that I started hearing very faint voices, which became unbearable as time went by, had severe delusions, OCD, and anxiety. So, I was really embarrassed about what i had inside my mind. I quietly suffered. Never thought that I am ill. Completed my undergrad anyhow(was a lot of struggle). In 2015, I decided I need to improvise on my career and thus went to the US for Masters. You would not believe me! due to huge changes(good changes) in environment and moving away from people who control my mind, insert thoughts, make me even walk or stand up,etc went away.After 2 semesters, I had poor grades and had to take college transfer. Then in 2017, my Masters was going well. But I had taken some herbal capsules from a store/Amazon 
for my anxiety. I had a severe panic attack. Went to ER. They gave me Ativan! and it made me feel great! So I decided to see a pdoc in Seattle. He wrote me Prozac(diagnosed GAD because i always used to hide actual symptoms because I thought either they are all in at me to control & torture me mentally/they will laugh at me). Prozac gave me severe akathisia. So pdoc told me maybe your diagnosis is wrong. I decided to take break and came to India to see a psychiatrist. I was diagnosed with Schizophrenia. Then started trials of meds. Some had horrible side effects/ some didnt work. But within 3 months of treatment, Amisulpride + Abilify + Prozac worked for me greatly but I gained about 50 pounds in 2 years/ suffered severe _NAME_ and testesterone was 1/4 of normal and prolactin was pretty high. Now till 2019 I was in USA, very stable. But as soon as I returned back to India due to some reasons, I was fed up with side effects. Doctor then gave me Clozapine 50mg + Amisulpride 800mg. That was the worst decision of 
my life! In 1.5 years I gained about 35 pounds and was sleeping for 15 hours/day and even then couldnt wake up. Now I decided to quit all my meds 4 weeks ago due to all side effects. As soon as I was tapered down slowly from meds by the doctor, I felt anxiety issues. My appetite was down to 1/5 of what I used to eat. Couldnt sleep at all. But I thought I dont need schizo meds. I WAS WRONG. since past 1 week I have been living in HELL. Had the most severe auditory hallucinations and voices and paranoia and delusions. So I decided to go back to the doctor. He promised me to start some good meds. Right now I am on Abilify 15mg/day, I dont have any side effects at all! And my hallucinations are gone but delusions are still 50% existent. Doctor told to go back to Clozapine if Iloperidone/Olanzapine/ Abilify doesnt work. So anyone here help me out with delusions that I have right now, even on Abilify? And is mind control, thought insertion really true? Or is this just a symptom? Which meds worked the best for you? 
And is there any way to control weight gain on Clozapine? Sorry for such a long post:(. Thanks for reading."
