The next couple of years went by with out much change. I thought that I was better even tho i still carried delusions and heard voices. 175930610,"My Sheikh, before he was anointed, spent forty days in seclusion, not talking to anyone, he spent a year without using money. These disciplines, traditionally for hermits and saints, have also proved invaluable to leaders. I have never gone a day without talking to someone, even if only on the phone. I have never gone a day without spending money since I first was given some on a regular basis. The extreme measures mentioned above of forty days and a year, are perhaps too difficult for most, and certainly for me at the moment, but I would like to try a day or so, and perhaps build up to a week or more. The purpose, as always with disciplines, is to become more conscious of reality. On the other hand, learning a craft seems to me to be more of a productive discipline to do. 174335628,"Okay. I understand. Just off your location I can already understand that it might be stressful for you. Truth is that, drs only say they take you off medication if they feel you are in a environment or that you have the resilience and stress management ability to manage triggers. Medication is a fail safe. For those of us with “psychotic disorder” and not “schizophrenia”, we are given medication so to prevent relapses which may go on to “cause” a case of “schizophrenia”. I would say, you are right to be confused and also to be frustrated. You have to be patient though. Do your best to be happy or stable before you meet a dr. And try to make sure it is consistent behaviour — this is how the dr judges whether or not, you are able to stay off medication. What is that you would like to achieve? No psychosis ever again, or no medication reliance? That’s the question I see in terms of what is being confused in terms of what you want from your healthcare provider."

174335638,"That's what I've been doing all last winter. I would just lay in bed all day and do nothing. I bought a SAD lamp and have been using it for hours every day for like 6 months since there was no sun this summer it was just cloudy. I use it to replace my bedroom light. Exercise helps too. Try writing down the change that you want in your life even if it includes anhedonia and depression but write down why you might be having those symptoms and what you desire in life. Without anhedonia, you can see beautiful things in life on the other side. Many people do things in life that we'd only imagine like travelling to different countries, talking to people (Find something to talk about, read stories, make your own stories), enjoying a variety of information and cool things that blow your mind every day. Anhedonia kills all of that. Saying I have anhedonia kind of kills any remaining hedonia that I have left and that remaining anhedonia is the key to opening the door for any more hedonia. I knew that in the 
back of my mind but it was so obvious that I ignored it. That's why psychiatrists revert you to therapy and family support and social interaction even though you have no desire and feel social anhedonia. The thing is for people to not judge our lack of caring about interacting with people and too depressed to laugh at jokes even though we know they're funny. If there was medication to fix anhedonia, that would be great but there isn't.. maybe mdma and ketamine but they're working on drugs to treat it finally and I'd say in the next 10 years, things would be great for schizophrenia."

175930773,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov The structure of paranoia in the general population. PE _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_ Steel, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, HI _PERSON_ and _NAME_, The British journal of psychiatry : the journal of mental science , Jun 2013 Psychotic phenomena appear to form a continuum with normal experience and beliefs, and may build on common emotional interpersonal concerns.We tested predictions that paranoid ideation is exponentially distributed and hierarchically arranged in the general population, and that persecutory ideas build on more common cognitions of mistrust, interpersonal sensitivity and ideas of reference.Items were chosen from the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV Axis II Disorders (SCID-II) questionnaire and the Psychosis Screening Questionnaire in the second British National Survey of Psychiatric Morbidity (n = 8580), to test a putative hierarchy of paranoid development using confirmatory factor analysis, latent class analysis and factor mixture modelling analys
is.Different types of paranoid ideation ranged in frequency from less than 2% to nearly 30%. Total scores on these items followed an almost perfect exponential distribution (r = 0.99). Our four a priori first-order factors were corroborated (interpersonal sensitivity; mistrust; ideas of reference; ideas of persecution). These mapped onto four classes of individual respondents: a rare, severe, persecutory class with high endorsement of all item factors, including persecutory ideation; a quasi-normal class with infrequent endorsement of interpersonal sensitivity, mistrust and ideas of reference, and no ideas of persecution; and two intermediate classes, characterised respectively by relatively high endorsement of items relating to mistrust and to ideas of reference.The paranoia continuum has implications for the aetiology, mechanisms and treatment of psychotic disorders, while confirming the lack of a clear distinction from normal experiences and processes."

175930796,"“Everyone is a genius, but if you judge a fish by its ability to climb a tree it will believe its whole life that it is stupid.” - _NAME_ - I wouldn’t worry about it. I’ve know people with very high IQ’s who suffered some kind of social or moral deficit. I heard one guy say one time, “For someone who is supposed to be smart, how come I am so dumb?” There was a book written a few decades ago called “Emotional Intelligence”. It said that traits like perseverance, altruism, social grace, and respect for authority make more of a difference in your potential success than raw intelligence. I once met a guy who had an IQ of 158, and he was totally dysfunctional. I believed him when he said he had an IQ of 158 because he knew a lot of vocabulary that I didn’t, and I have a pretty good vocabulary. He wasn’t a nice person. They say that serial killers generally have a high IQ. The main thing is to find some kind of way in life where you are doing something you like at your job and you h
ave a warm and supportive family and you feel okay about yourself. Make the best out of bad situations. Things will get easier as you grow older."

175930826,"Don’t worry about what other people will think, believe, or feel. It’s your business if you want to work or not, or if you even feel like you can or not. I was literally in the same position just a few months ago where I felt like a failure and I felt like everyone was going to judge me if I didn’t work. 175930844,Benzo’s are short acting/addictive but really a good option for some. Put one under your tongue and it’s in your bloodstream quickly and help… …But. 174335673,"Say what you want about the hallucinations,but the person with sz feels them as an untamed psychological entities that cannot be domesticated at all . The hallucination creature,he has all options to be what he wants,but he prefers to be destructive,brutal and provocative with the human host,he do not care about the consequence of his actions The hallucination entity,he has all the option to behave what is good or bad with all possible degrees,but he involves eternal enmity towards what is human, therefore he insists on choosing the evil as approach method to managing his behavior against the human host Psychiatry should study well the behavioral characteristics of the hallucinations as a psychological entity before focusing all effort on enumerating the behavioral responses outputs of the human person,for sake understanding what is going on the higher cognitive processes which precede the behavior production The hallucination entity affects his human host in any interactive situation through speci
fic cognitive culture data that predetermines his behavior towards the host Regard with the person with sz In a way,it imagined for him that he sees a moved people (in reality,he does not imagine any persons in his imagination theater by his conscious will ) It seems to the mind’s perception that the imaginary people moved from place to other in the external environment (while they did not move) They make him feeling the fear from them inside himself even if he did not feel the fear !"

175931065,"Four score and seven years ago I was at work. Well actually, it was only just four years ago. I was emptying wastebaskets in the warehouse and all of sudden it hit me like a thunderbolt. I work in an Army Reserve office building amongst soldiers and our crew. And I thought, “Everybody here hates me.” I was a 100 percent sure of it. It was a really bad feeling but I had to just keep doing my job. And so I finished the wastebaskets and just kept going to work but I walked around with that feeling. And so a year went by thinking this. And I don’t think anyone deliberately took advantage of me but people were treating me different, a little condescending, a little superior. But funny enough, there were about three of the office workers who always greeted me and were always friendly during this time. But in my state of mind I thought they really were acting. But they were consistently nice. After a year, one day I was on my break sitting in the lobby and a woman who I had seen for the past two yea
rs saw me as she walked by and looked at me, gave me a big smile and said hi. And somehow it dawned on me that she was sincere. And I perked up and started looking at people closer and I realized that many people actually liked me. I came out of my depression and started smiling to people and saying hi. And I realized I had been wrong the whole year. And I started talking to people and cracking jokes again. Life turned good at work. This ending is kind of anti-climatic but now I thought that everybody liked me. And that’s how the last two years have been. I get to talk with everybody and be friendly and make people laugh. My friend at work even noticed the change and commented that I’m a lot friendlier. The anti-climatic part is that for the past week I’ve been thinking the reality might be that maybe 4 or 5 people might really like me and the rest are just polite or maybe just think I’m just OK. I know quite a few people dislike me but I get along with most people including my co-workers. So I don’
t know what I expect you guys to get out of this, but hopefully something. You tell me. And most importantly, “Four score years” is 80 years. Right, _NAME_?"

175931096,"I have experienced antipsychotics (and also antidepressants) as causing very real and severe withdrawals, with both physical symptoms and emotional ones (mood swings, out of character anger, psychosis, suicidality). So have others i know. I think it is fair if people are told that from the start. I dont think people crave for an antipsychotic as with a benzo or heroin, but withdrawals are very real. What is the difference between heroin withdrawal, alcohol withdrawal or zyprexa withdrawal?"

175931124,"Substance use, in my experience, makes sz symptoms worse. I find being off sugar and caffeine to be helpful, as well. And, yeah, I was a heavy cannabis user, and though I didn’t drink often, when I did I got falling-down drunk. Once I quit it didn’t take too long before I saw the sz symptoms get less intrusive. One pdoc I had said the meds become more effective the “cleaner” your inner body is. When I quit smoking I was amazed at how much better I felt, and meds halved in the 1st three months. Less meds=fewer side effects. It’s awesome. Nutcase"

175931142,"I can get lower leg cramps when I reduce a sleep medicine. I can get chest pain from time to time, especially when I lay down at night. For this, I keep a heating pad plugged in and laying on my bed and can just cut it on and apply it. You might want to buy a heating pad and apply it to your chest while laying down or sitting up watching TV. A moist heating pad might work better, by moistening the insert that comes with the heating pad, by putting water on it and squeezing it out. If there is no insert, you can take a small towel and moisten that. I think your doctor would have mentioned by now if it was your heart. After all, this happened right when you went off medicine. A warm bath could help, also. Heat expands the blood vessels, including those in the chest muscles, and that extra flow of oxygen and nutrients to the injured area could be a benefit."

175931153,"Coronavirus puts drug repurposing on a fast track Last month, Hangzhou-based Ascletis Pharma applied to the Chinese authorities to test two HIV protease inhibitors (ritonavir and [ASC09] in clinical trials to treat COVID-19, the illness caused by the new coronavirus (Table 1). And Suzhou-based BrightGene Bio-Medical Technology announced in early February that it would begin to manufacture Gilead Sciences’ remdesivir (GS-5734), a broad-spectrum investigational antiviral, as a treatment for coronavirus infection. Remdesivir, originally developed to treat Ebola virus and then dropped, will also be tested by Gilead in partnership [with Chinese health authorities] in randomized, controlled [trials]. “The general genomic layout and the general replication kinetics and the biology of the MERS, SARS and [SARS-CoV-2] viruses are very similar, so testing drugs which target relatively generic parts of these coronaviruses is a logical step,” says _NAME_, chief, Viral Ecology Unit, US National Institute o
f Health. Testing therapies approved for other indications also makes senses, as these drugs are already mass produced and available on a large scale. = Nature 27/02/20"

175931195,"Sometimes I like to look back on how I was on this forum a year ago or two years ago. I remember back in 2018 I wanted to be more like a older friend of mine who was an accountant and married with kids. They lived in a nice home in the city. I wanted to work FT like her and have free time to go on outings or running at the beach, and to drive. I still want those things one day, but my functioning used to be so much better before my latest episode. Now I just look up to the people I meet at Women’s Group. Most of them work despite mental illness. I like how they talk about finances. I’d like to hustle at my job and buy a car and afford things like my own gas money every month. I’d also like to get on ssdi one day instead of ssi. I see single moms from group with mi and I feel like having kids would be worth it no matter what, one day. But for now I just want to be like the women in Women’s Group and really be able to take care of myself and pull my own weight at home and in life in general."
